flores_passage: Smaller organisms (a smaller population) often find themselves in a different environment from the main population they came from (eg if they move past a mountainous area or across a river or to a new island from which they cannot easily return). This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new species needs different traits or adaptations to be a stronger competitor than was needed before. The original species has never changed, they still want the same optimization as before. Over time, as the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, their similarities to other populations become less and less common. Eventually, after thousands or millions of years, the two populations become so different in appearance that they cannot be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which means making new offspring. Making new species is an inevitable consequence and an essential part of evolution.
